It's also kind of why the light refracts blue when you look up the sky because it's full of water. Oh and not to mention that the light is bouncing off the water in the ocean which is also got a blue tint which bounces the blue backup into the sky which refracts it even more creating even more blue. What's with you guys? That's twice today I've heard someone say that there is no atmosphere on the moon. Yes the moon does have an atmosphere! It's just incredibly thin and for all intents and purposes that we think of you could say it doesn't have an atmosphere, but then you would technically be wrong. Someone down the line that listened to you will be incredibly disappointed when that very technical point happens to come up. Along those same lines space isn't completely void of everything & it's not a true vacuum. Instead there's varying degrees of matter floating around out there but relative to what we're used to on the surface of Earth you could say that it's a vacuum.
Now you could say that I am being overly facetious about a minutiae that everyday people could care less about and that's true, but like Einstein says it's all relative. To completely obstigate the minutiae is to deny the truth for the sake of convenience.

Thanks for the video. However, you're partially correct about reason for stars not being visible in the Apollo photos taken on the moon. The biggest reason for that is due to the small aperture setting on the Apollo camera to avoid overexposing photos due to the intensely bright sunlight. With such a small aperture setting, stars are not bright enough for the camera to capture them.

Here on Earth, one could easily test this fact by taking a photo of a full moon with increasingly small aperture settings on the camera. Decreasing the aperture will cause the stars to eventually disappear from the photos, but the moon will look better. Increasing the aperture, on the other hand, will allow more light into the camera to capture the stars, but the moon will become overexposed in the photos.

After reading the reviews on it, I found out that that the atmosphere is completely nonexistent.

While atmospheric diffusion does not take place on the moon, shadows may still be lit indirectly, by light reflecting off of nearby objects (astronauts, rocks, etc.). In essence, everything illuminated by the sun is just a very inefficient mirror. This is why in many images taken on the moon, the shadows ARENT in fact totally black.

Part of the reason shadows appear so dark on the moon is the fact that the exposure of the cameras was very low in order to avoid being washed out by the bright light.

I'm sure the absence of light scattering atmosphere is a cause for the lack of a colored sky (read black) on the moon, but the reason it is completely black is the same reason the shadows are completely black, and its not because of a lack of scattering.

Its contrast in camera exposure.

Because the surface of the moon reflects so much light the exposure settings on the camera will not allow light from such dark sources sufficient time to expose the film. Shutter speed is going to be high, and aperture size narrow.

If the exposure settings were to be recomputed to capture enough light from the stars and from the penumbra of a cast shadow on the moon, everything else would be entirely over exposed and completely white and absent detail. And there is evidence of this in those pictures. While the shadows are extremely dark they do have penumbrae, albeit very small just at the edges. This represents the very small area where the mathematics of camera exposure allow some shadowed detail to be captured with the luminous detail.

You can perform this experiment yourself with a piece of white paper with a drawing on it, a bright light, and a darkened room with just enough light to see the image on the paper with the naked eye without additional light, using a single lens reflex camera without HDR or with HDR off.

If you shine light directly at the paper and take a picture of it you will find that the requisite shutter speed and aperture settings necessary to have a the drawing visible make everything else dark, while if you recompute the exposure to see detail in the darkened room around the paper, the detail on the paper will be overexposed and not visible.

This is why no stars are visible in the night sky on the moon in pictures, and why the shadows are so dark. The human eye cheats. It doesn't use one camera, but many (rods and cones in the retina) all with their own exposure needs, and the benefit of a brain to add the details.

Modern cameras with HDR or High Dynamic Range get around this problem by literally taking multiple pictures simultaneously at multiple different exposure settings and then combining them into one image to balance the light and dark, which is why the above experiment will fail if your camera has HDR.

This made for some of the most famous shots on the moon and is the origin for some "faked the moon landing" conspiracies, but is in fact caused by light being reflected back off the moon's surface, which acts like bike reflectors, sending some light back on more or less the same trajectory as it came in on, regardless of the angle of the ground.

This was demonstrated nicely by nvidia in a ray tracing demonstration for their (at the time) new RTX cards.

The reason the light hitting your eyes is mostly blue (and green, making cyan) is because the light that bounces off air molecules is blue and green. That's also why sunsets are yellow, orange and red. Because the yellow, orange and red light don't get bounced around. They go straight through while the blue and green light shine down on the people to the west of you.

What's interesting is shadows are also affeced by your eyes colour balance. Sunlight has a slight yellow tint, but when your eyes are adjusted it looks white, making shadows bluer. But if you're in shadow and focus on that, light becomes more yellow.
This works with sunsets too, here shadows become green tinted with the orange light from the sun (sun light goes through more of the atmosphere making it orange)
Likewise the cyan sky is lit up by scattered light from the sun, but it only becomes cyan because the backdrop behind is black empty space.
Light on the moon works like video-games without raytraced global illumination.

I disagree with your premise, at least at the Apollo landing sites (deep craters maybe dark and also the reason of water is believed to be frozen inpolar craters)Having been an advocate for NASA and fighting the Moon hoaxers for most of my life, the hoaxers would question why such images as the one with an astronaut descending the leg of the LEM in shadow, showed him clearly without the surroundings out of shadow being overexposed., as evidence it was filmed on a well lit set . The vital point here was the dust on the moon hadn’t been eroded by water, like on Earth, so under a magnifying glass, Earth sand looks rounded where lunar dust has sharp edges and flat surfaces. It was so potentially gritty there was a concern the soil would cut through the suits, especially on folds, like elbows and knees. So there was plenty of light even in the shadows, reflected off the flat surfaces of the soil which is everywhere. Because the surrounds out of shadow were so bright getting the exposure balance was difficult so the shadows and the sky would look pitch black in the photos at times. That’s why no stars are visible, ie due to being under exposed even though we know they are there.
